newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX crude called higher tracking IPE Brent.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX crude called higher tracking IPE Brent.

text.p: NYMEX crude was called five to ten cents higher Thursday tracking gains by Brent futures on London's IPE and expiry-related buying of gas oil there.
New signs that OPEC will maintain its production ceiling when it meets next month in Vienna were deemed by dealers to be neutral for oil prices here.
"We are following the strength in London. The OPEC news maintains the status quo, so I don't see it being a factor," said Victor Yu, vice president at Refco Inc in New York.
Refined products were called steady to 0.25 cent a gallon higher.
June Brent was five cents higher at $18.21 a barrel on the IPE while May gas oil was 50 cents higher at $168.00 a tonne.
Gasoline ended with healthy gains Wednesday on talk of refinery snags and after oil inventory data showed tightening supplies. Dealers said gasoline is becoming the oil complex's linchpin.

On Wednesday, June unleaded gasoline ended up 0.61 cent at 60.92 cents a gallon after rising to session high of 61.65 cents. June crude settled four cents a barrel lower at $19.62 while June heating oil finished 0.45 cent a gallon lower at 53.08 cents.
"Basically its unleaded that is holding us up, so if gasoline doesn't break down then crude won't," said a New York crude dealer.
Meanwhile, OPEC President Libyan Oil Minister Abdullah Salem al-Badri said on Thursday he expected the group to stick with its 25.03 million bpd output ceiling when OPEC meets in Vienna in June.
He said the quota would be maintained for another six months until end-1997 despite widespread quota busting which has carried output almost two million bpd above official allocations.
Seven OPEC ministers have scheduled talks in Isfahan later on Thursday to discuss quota violations which have helped knock $7 a barrel off oil prices since the turn of the year.
